skills.name: Hiragana 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Welcome to the Japanese course!

While many consider Japanese to be very difficult to learn for native English speakers, this is only partially true. Many aspects of the Japanese language are quite simple, such as the sound system, and yes, even most of the grammar.

Writing Systems

Japanese uses three different writing systems, hiragana, katakana, and kanji.

Hiragana is the most basic Japanese syllabary. It's like an alphabet that uses syllables instead of individual sounds.

Katakana is the syllabary used to write foreign words and some noises. Although it's different from hiragana, it represents the exact same syllables.

Kanji are Chinese characters used in the Japanese language to write individual nouns, verbs, and adjectives. Kanji are not phonetic, meaning you need to memorize each pronunciation individually. In this course, we introduce kanji gradually and methodically.

Hiragana Pronunciation

Below are the most basic forms of Japanese hiragana. We'll be introducing some more later as well.

Japanese IPA, Notes
[a]
[i]
[], like the oo in food
[e]
[o]
[ka]
[ki]
[k]
[ke]
[ko]
[sa]
[i], like the shee in sheep
[s], although it can shorten to more of a [s] at the end of a word
[se]

[ta]
[ti], like the tch in itchy
[ts], like the ts in cats
[te]

[na]

[n]
[ne]
[no]
[ha], although pronounced like [a] or "wa" as a particle
[i], like the h in human
[], roughly between a short "hoo" and "foo"
[he], although pronounced like [e] or "eh" as a particle
[ho]
[ma]
[mi]
[m]
[me]
[mo]
[ja]
[j]
[jo]
[a], like the t in the American pronunciation of butter
[i]
[]

[o]
[a]
[o], although it's most often romanized as "wo"
[n] or [], like the n in pink, producing a [m] when combined with a bilabial stop, hence "tempura" and not "tenpura"

As the only solitary consonant in hiragana, is especially notable because it is only found at the end of another syllable. In other words, you will never read a Japanese word that begins with

Enjoy the course!

skills.name: Hiragana 4
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In the following skill, we introduce a few more elements to basic hiragana.

Hiragana Part II: Dakuten

Putting two little dashes or dakuten at the upper right corner of a hiragana syllable voices the consonant. It changes the pronunciation of the hiragana in the following way:

Sound Sound with Dakuten Example
k g (ka) (ga)
s z (sa) (za), (shi) (ji)*
t d (ta) (da), (tsu) (zu)*
h b (ha) (ba)

Putting a little circle or handakuten at the upper right corner changes the pronunciation of the ---- hiragana in the following way:

Sound Sound with Handakuten Example
h p (ha) (pa)

Hiragana Part III: Small

Putting a (small tsu) between two hiragana syllables doubles the letter right after and introduces a short pause between two sounds. See some examples below:

Without With
(kite) (kitte)
(moto) (motto)
(asari) (assari)

Hiragana Part IV: Big and Small Characters

Lastly, this skill introduces the big and small versions of three sounds in hiragana. A small or changes the pronunciation of a word in the following way:

Big -- Small --
[ki-ya] [kya]
[ki-yu] [kyu]
[ki-yo] [kyo]

The small character changes the two-syllable construction into a one-syllable construction. Sometimes, the difference can lead to a real change in meaning, as shown below:

Big Small
[bi-y-in] "beauty salon" [by-in] "hospital"

skills.name: Greetings
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Saying Thank You

The phrase "thank you" in Japanese is dependent on the situation. Below is a table of the most common forms, from least to most formal. Note that the formality increases with the length of the phrase.

Japanese Explanation
Thanks, used with friends.
Thank you, used with friends.
Thank you very much, used with friends.
Thank you, used with strangers, teachers, and bosses.
Thank you very much, used with strangers, teachers, and bosses.

Saying Thank You for a Past Action

If you'd like to thank someone for something they did in the past, you change the ending to

Japanese Explanation
Thank you for what you did, used with strangers, teachers, and bosses.
Thank you very much for what you did, used with strangers, teachers, and bosses.

skills.name: Katakana 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Katakana

This lesson will begin introducing katakana. Like hiragana, katakana is a Japanese phonetic writing system. It's used for several things, but one of the most common uses is for foreign words.

Japanese IPA, Notes
[a]
[e]
[o]
[i]
[i]
[a], like the t in the American pronunciation of butter
[ka]
[me]
[ki]
[], roughly between a short "hoo" and "foo"
[ko]
[ma]
[i], like the shee in sheep
[n] or [], like the n in pink, producing a [m] when combined with a bilabial stop, hence "tempura" and not "tenpura"
[s], although it can shorten to more of a [s] at the end of a word
[ta]
[o]
[jo]
long vowel mark, used to extend the vowel sound that precedes it

Katakana with Dakuten

Japanese IPA, Notes
[gi]
[di], like the jee in jeep
[pa]
[pi]

If you sound out the words below using katakana characters, you might find some familiar words! Some of the pronunciation is a little different than its English equivalent, though.

Japanese Romaji English
kamera camera
Amerika the US
Maria Maria (female given name)
Afurika Africa
Mekishiko Mexico
Furansu France
Erika Erika (female given name)
Mario Mario (male given name)

Just be careful - not all words written in katakana were taken from English!

Japanese Romaji English
Igirisu the UK
Itaria Italy
Rma Rome

Not all foreign loan words in Japanese are directly equivalent to their English counterparts! For instance, in Japanese (Amerika) isn't commonly used to refer to all of North America or to both North and South America - it's used almost exclusively to mean "the United States." However, (Igirisu) can be used to refer to both "the UK" and "England."

skills.name: Introduction
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Introduction to Kanji

This lesson introduces the non-phonetic writing system of Japanese, kanji. Kanji literally means "Chinese characters," and they're used to build content words like nouns, verbs, and adjectives.

Kanji Readings

So how do you read kanji? Most kanji have at least two possible readings. Typically, one reading is derived from a native Japanese word, and one reading is derived from a Chinese loanword. These are called "kunyomi" ("meaning reading") and "onyomi" ("sound reading") respectively.

Let's take the kanji for "country," On its own, we use the Japanese "kunyomi" reading, In Japanese, means "country." However, in compounds, we use the "onyomi" reading of Therefore, China, or "middle country," is read as

Rendaku

So why isn't it This is due to a phenomenon known as "rendaku" or "sequential voicing." Syllables that come later in a word are sometimes voiced and marked with a dakuten. This is often rather unpredictable, so rendaku words should be memorized individually.

Example Kanji

Below is a table of the six kanji that are introduced in this lesson, complete with possible readings.

Kanji Meaning Kunyomi Reading Onyomi Reading
Person
Middle
Country
Sun, Day
Origin, Book
Rice Paddy

You may have noticed that the word Japan, or is composed of the kanji meaning "sun" and "origin." This word was first adopted by the Chinese, and to them, Japan was off to the east, the place where the sun rose or "originated."

Katakana Pronunciation

This lesson also introduces katakana, the phonetic Japanese writing system used for foreign words. See their pronunciation below.

Basic Katakana

skills.name: Introduction 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Basic Grammar

One thing that makes Japanese very different from English is the Japanese tendency to drop the subject of the sentence when the meaning is clear from context. Statements usually refer to oneself, while questions usually address the person you're speaking with.

The Question Marker

Adding question marker at the end will make the affirmative (positive) sentence into question. If the sentences end in , its easy to formulate questions by using

Positive Question
(Im American.) (Are you American?)
(Im a student.) (Are you a student?)

Pronouns

Pronouns are relatively rare in Japanese, but they are sometimes used to explicitly specify the subject or topic of a sentence. Below are some of the most common ones.

Person Singular Plural
First is used in polite settings by women and men, used by women in most other settings. is used by men in informal settings. is most common. sounds rather stiff and business-like.
Second is used in polite settings, however, if you know someone's name, it's best to call them by their name, typically followed by or is used by men in informal settings, specifically to those on or beneath one's social level. is used in formal settings, and is used in informal settings, especially to subordinates.
Third - Male is also used for a mixed-gendered group
Third - Female

Kanji from this Skill

Below is a table of the eight kanji that are introduced in this lesson, complete with possible readings.

Kanji Meaning Kunyomi Reading Onyomi Reading
Education
Born, Raw
Previous
English
Language
What
Name
Before

skills.name: Food 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Object Particle

The marker is attached to things or people, and means that they are the target of the verb. Subjects are often omitted in Japanese sentences. Unlike English, the location of the verbs are usually at the end of the sentence. was once pronounced wo, but now its the [o] sound.

Object Verb English
I drink water.
I eat fish.

General Pronouns

This lesson also introduces the general pronouns and which translate to "this," "that," "that (over there)," and "which (one)," respectively.
Japanese
English this that that (over there) which
Notes closer to the speaker closer to the listener far from both the speaker and listener question

Kanji from this Skill

Below is a table of the two kanji that are introduced in this skill, complete with possible readings.

Kanji Meaning Kunyomi Reading Onyomi Reading
Water
Eat

skills.name: Time
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Kanji from this Skill

Below is a table of the six kanji that are introduced in this skill, complete with possible readings.

Kanji Meaning Kunyomi Reading Onyomi Reading
One
Two
Three
Time
Now
Minute, Part

skills.name: Routines
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Directional Particle

The particle indicates a direction towards which something or someone moves. This movement is the direction away from the current location. When used as a particle, is pronounced as [e].

Location and Time Particle

The particle with a time expression indicates a specific point in time. can also express times on a clock, days of the week, or years.

Direction English Location or Time English
to the office at 3 oclock
to school on Monday
to Japan in May
to America in 2016

Kanji from this Skill

Below is a table of the four kanji that are introduced in this skill, complete with possible readings.

Kanji Meaning Kunyomi Reading Onyomi Reading
Go
School
Noon
After

skills.name: Home 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The Verbs and

and are very special verbs in Japanese that refer to something's existence. They're often translated into English as "there is" or "there are." Even though they're often translated identically, they describe different objects:

  • is used for inanimate objects, like books, rooms, televisions, and apples.
  • is used for animate objects, like people, cats, dogs, and other animals.

Japanese Counting Words

The Japanese language uses special counting words to count things, actions, and events. You use these words when you want to mention a specific number of a certain noun. Below is how they are typically formed.

Noun Particle Number + Counter Verb
  • means "there are two birds."

In Japanese, you also have the option of placing the number and counter before the noun, but this is less common and typically involves an additional particle.

Number + Counter Noun Particle Verb
  • also means "there are two birds."

Below is a table for the counting word introduced in this lesson. is a counter used just for birds and rabbits.

Number Form of
or

Kanji from this Skill

Below you will find the kanji for all of the vocabulary words in this skill.

Kanji Hiragana Meaning Components
kitchen pedestal + place
room division + dwelling
bath wind + spine
yard, garden
house
window
cat
dog
bird
chair chair + small thing
desk

skills.name: Introduction 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Sentence-Ending Particles

This lesson introduces two of the most common sentence-ending particles, and Used exclusively in conversation, they communicate intention rather than concrete meaning, and as such, they are difficult to translate directly.

is used to seek passive agreement from the person being spoken to, much like "... right?" or "... correct?" in English.

  • () means "nice weather, isn't it?" and is a common expression on mild, sunny days.

is used to express certainty in a matter of uncertainty, as if to emphasize the truth of the words that come before it. This sense of emphasis mirrors the use of the word "does" in the English sentence "She (actually) does enjoy tennis."

  • () means "are you doing well?" and a valid response would be as follows.

  • () means "I am doing well (you know)" and communicates that perhaps the answerer's health was actually poor recently and they intend to underline their present healthiness.

skills.name: Counting
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Japanese Counting Words

The Japanese language uses special counting words to count things, actions, and events. Below is a table for and the counting words introduced in this lesson. is a counter that can be used for anything, while is restricted to physical objects that are relatively small and round.

Number Form of Form of

skills.name: Family 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Familial Terms

Japanese uses a number of terms for family members. Some use the honorific form, which is typically reserved for someone else's family members, while others use a shorter, more casual form, reserved for your own family members.

Still, these rules are not hard and fast. You will still hear children use the honorific form to address their own mother or father.

Family Member Honorific Form Personal Form
Older Brother () ()
Older Sister () ()
Younger Brother () ()
Younger Sister () ()
Child () ()
Parents () ()
Father () ()
Mother () ()
Grandfather () ()
Grandmother () ()
Uncle Older than Parent () ()
Aunt Older than Parent () ()
Uncle Younger than Parent () ()
Aunt Younger than Parent () ()
Husband () ()
Wife () ()

skills.name: Restaurant
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Determiners

Just like in English, determiners in Japanese come before a noun and signify both its location and relationship with the speaker. Japanese also has two words for "that" depending on whether or not the listener is close to the noun or not.

  • () () means "this book is expensive" when the book in question is close to you but farther from the person you're speaking to.

  • () () means "that book is expensive" when the book in question is far from you but near the person you're speaking to.

  • () () means "that book is expensive" when the book in question is far away from both you and the person you're speaking to.

  • () () means "which book is expensive?" no matter where the book in question happens to be.

Place Marker

The particle usually shows the location of action or event, such as "at" "in" or "on" in English. also indicates "with" "by" or "using" to show a language or tools being used.

Adjectives

This lesson also introduces Japanese adjectives, which are divided into -adjectives and -adjectives.

-Adjectives

-adjectives are true adjectives that have been in the Japanese language since the very beginning. All of them end in although not all adjectives that end in are in fact -adjectives. See how they operate using the example -adjective meaning "delicious."

Sentence Translation
This is delicious.

Note that all -adjectives can drop the ending in casual speech. This is grammatical as well.

Sentence Translation
This is delicious.

When placed before a noun, there's no change to the spelling of an -adjective.

Sentence Translation
It is delicious sushi.

We will be introducing the other major category of Japanese adjectives later in the course.

Large Numbers

Japanese has certain conventions for writing large numbers. Below are the kanji and readings for a few of them that will be introduced in this lesson.

Japanese English
() one hundred
() one thousand
() ten thousand

and can be used in isolation to mean 100 and 1,000.

Example Translation
() 100 yen
() 1,000 yen

It would sound unnatural in Japanese to write or when you have 100 or 1,000 of something. However, functions with the opposite convention; when you have 10,000 of something, it is customary to put in front of it.

Example Translation
() 10,000 yen

skills.name: Activity 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Past Tense

This lesson introduces the past tense of verbs. In Japanese, there are other varieties of tense, but we will cover those in later lessons. Changing a verb from the present/future tense to the past tense is rather simple.

  • () means either "I will eat bread" or "I eat bread."
  • () means "I ate bread."
Verb Tense Positive Ending
Present
Future
Past

Instead of changing the negative ending to make a negative past tense verb ("did not eat"), we simply add the word to the end.

  • () means either "I will not eat bread" or "I do not eat bread."
  • () means "I did not eat bread."
Verb Tense Negative Ending
Present
Future
Past

The endings above apply to all verbs that end with

skills.name: Position
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Expressing Position

As noted in an earlier lesson, Japanese has two special verbs that mean "be" or "exist" depending on the animateness of the subject. is used for living things, while is used for inanimate objects. We use these verbs to describe someone or something's position relative to something else.

Topic Location Directional Verb
  • means "the cat is on the desk."
Topic Location Directional Verb
  • means "the book is on the desk."

Notice how the verb changes depending on whether or not the topic is animate.

skills.name: Hobby 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Counting People

Counting people in Japanese is relatively easy, but there are a couple irregular forms. Please reference the following table to learn how to count people.

Number Form of

You will also see another counter, (), which is used to count flat things. Thankfully, has no irregular forms, and so it's read the same way regardless of the number that comes before it.

Not Much

is a word you can use with negative sentences to express ideas like not much, not often or not many. Below are a few examples of its usage.

Japanese English
I do not watch a lot of movies.
I do not go on walks very often.

skills.name: Family 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Familial Terms

Japanese uses a number of terms for family members. Some use the honorific form, which is typically reserved for someone else's family members, while others use a shorter, more casual form, reserved for your own family members.

Still, these rules are not hard and fast. You will still hear children use the honorific form to address their own mother or father.

Family Member Honorific Form Personal Form
Husband () ()
Wife () ()
Child () ()
Grandfather () ()
Grandmother () ()

Not your uncle but your grandfather!

Sometimes, changing just one character can entirely change the meaning of a word. Japanese learners often make this mistake with the words for uncle/grandfather and aunt/grandmother. Please double-check the length of your vowel!

Japanese English
uncle
grandfather
aunt
grandmother

Arriving and Departing Phrases

This skill also teaches a special set of Japanese phrases when someone enters or exits a home. These are in widespread use throughout Japan.

One makes the statement when one either departs from or arrives in a home, and one makes the response upon hearing the corresponding statement.

Statement Response
When Departing
Translation "I'm leaving!" "Take care!"
When Returning
Translation "I'm home!" "Welcome back!"

skills.name: Transportation 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Negative -Adjectives

When -adjectives are switched from positive to negative, they undergo a spelling change. The characteristic -ending switches to a and the phrase meaning "not" is added to the end. The final result is an ending such as See the example below.

Sentence Translation
This is delicious.
This is not delicious.

Just like with positive -adjectives, all negative -adjectives can drop the ending in casual speech.

Sentence Translation
This is not delicious.

To make the speech more formal, one can change the ending from to

Sentence Translation
This is not delicious.

skills.name: Clothes 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Wearing Clothing

Japanese has many translations for the English words "to wear" or "to put on," depending on where on the body the clothes are worn. Below are some examples taught in this lesson.

Japanese Notes
wear, on the whole body or upper body
wear, on the head
wear, on the lower body

skills.name: Hobby 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Together!

In Japanese, there are different ways to ask someone to do something with you. Your verb ending can subtly change the nature of your request or suggestion.

Verb Ending Meaning in English
~ "Would you like to...?" / "Do you want to...?"
~ "Let's..."
~ "Shall we...?" / "Should we...?"
Japanese English
Would you like to swim at the pool?
Let's swim at the pool.
Shall we swim at the pool?

Weeks and Months

Japanese has specific words for ideas like "last week," "next week" and "this week." There is even a word for "the week after next"! Maybe you'll notice a pattern with how these words are formed!

Word Reading Meaning
this month
next month
last month
Word Reading Meaning
this week
next week
last week
the week after next

Playing an Instrument

Japanese uses different verbs to talk about playing different kinds of musical instruments. In this skill, you will encounter the verb used for playing a string instrument - (). Don't forget that the piano is included as a string instrument!

Japanese English
I play the piano.
I play the guitar.

skills.name: Weather 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Isn't it?

In Japanese, it is common to ask a question in the negative form in order to solicit agreement. These sentences are commonly translated as "Isn't it...?" in English.

Japanese English
Is it dark?
Isn't it dark?

Did you notice the difference? When the question is asked with a regular adjective form, the English meaning is "Is it...?" When it is asked with an adjective in the negative form, the English translation changes to "Isn't it...?"

Adverbs

In Japanese, you can change an - adjective to an adverb by dropping the - and replacing it with -. Adverbs are usually words that end in -ly in English and describe how something happens.

Adjective Meaning Adverb Meaning
() strong () strongly
() weak () weakly

Here are some examples of how these different forms are used.

Japanese English
The wind is strong.
A strong wind blows.
The wind blows strongly.

skills.name: Food 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Very, quite, or not at all!

In this skill, you will encounter words that can modify the severity of your sentences.

() and () can both be used with negative sentences to mean "not at all."

Japanese English
These vegetables are not delicious at all.
There is not much milk at all.

and () can both be used in affirmative sentences to mean "very."

Japanese English
This ramen is very tasty.
It is very tasty.

() can be used in affirmative sentences to mean "quite."

Japanese English
There is quite a lot of salt, isn't there?

A Small Amount

() is an adjective that means few or not much. Be careful although the word ends in -, it isnt the negative form of the adjective! The negative form of is actually (). Thats a mouthful!

Japanese English
There is not much curry.

skills.name: Food 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
An Empty Stomach

In Japanese, when you ask someone if they are hungry, the expression is ()

Although the Japanese expression is written in past tense, its understood meaning would be equivalent to the English expression Are you hungry? It literally translates to something like, Has your stomach been emptied? because if your stomach has become empty, that means that youre hungry now!

skills.name: Dates
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Japanese Counting Words

The Japanese language uses special counting words to count things, actions, and events. Below is a table for the counting word introduced in this lesson. is the counter for days.

Number Form of

skills.name: Shopping 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
-Adjectives

This lesson teaches the first -adjective in the course, meaning "pretty" or "clean." Although it looks like an -adjective, it belongs to the -adjective category.

-adjectives are nominal adjectives that have been imported from other countries over centuries, mainly from China. There is no pattern as to what they look like, aside from the fact they're not likely to end in an Remember that is an exception. See how they operate using the example of below.

Sentence Translation
This is pretty.

Note that -adjectives typically do not drop the ending in a construction like the one above.

When placed before a noun, a -adjective adds a characteristic between the adjective and the noun that follows.

Sentence Translation
It is a pretty flower.

skills.name: People 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
People 1

Japanese verbs, including the copula can be used as they are with any subject, regardless of gender or number. This means that Japanese sentences often have many possible English equivalents.

Japanese English
He's a student.
She's a student.
They're students.

This skill introduces several words that describe people. You can reference them below.

Japanese English
"gakusei" student
"tomodachi" friend
"isha" doctor
"sensei" teacher

skills.name: Activity 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
-Form

The -form or -form of a verb is a very important grammatical construct in Japanese that is used in several contexts.

Requests

/ + is used for requests. It means "please + [verb]"

  • means "please read."

You can also attach nouns to these requests to get more specific.

  • means "please read the book."
English Short Form Polite Form Request
do
read
turn on
close
open

skills.name: Nature 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
What was happening?

/ + can be used to describe continuing action in the present, but did you know that you can use the - form of the verb to describe continuing action in the past, too? Instead of , you would use after the - form of a verb to describe an ongoing action that occurred in the past. Look at how the verb endings can change the meaning of a sentence.

Japanese English
It rains
It is raining
It rained
It was raining

Counting Small Animals

Japanese has a lot of counter words that change depending on the object or creature being counted. Sometimes, the counter word even depends on the size of the thing being counted! For instance, the counter word () is used to count small animals. However, the reading of the word changes depending on the number that comes before it.

Kanji Reading Meaning
(ippiki) one (small animal)
(nihiki) two (small animals)
(sanbiki) three (small animals)
(yonhiki) four (small animals)
(gohiki) five (small animals)
(roppiki) six (small animals)
(nanahiki) seven (small animals)
(happiki) eight (small animals)
(kyuuhiki) nine (small animals)
(juppiki) ten (small animals)

The Water Radical

Kanji characters are made up of different component parts called radicals. Did you know that a kanji's radicals can sometimes give you a hint about the kanji's meaning? For instance, kanji containing the radical often have something to do with water. If you look at the words below, you can see that they all contain the radical on the left side of the kanji character, and all of them involve water. You might have noticed this radical in other kanji you've already seen, too!

Kanji Reading Meaning
sea
pond
swim

skills.name: Classroom
skills.tipsAndNotes:
-Form

We will now take a look at three more purposes for the -form of verbs.

Ongoing Actions

/ + is used for actions in progress.

  • means "I am reading."

We also use this construction for ongoing actions that would ordinarily use the present perfect construction in English.

  • means "The movie has begun."

/ + is the corresponding negative construction.

  • means "I am not reading."
English Short Form Polite Form Ongoing Action
do
read
eat
drink

Prohibitions

+ + is used when telling someone that they must not or should not do something.

  • means "you must not read."

  • means "you must not read that book."

English Short Form Polite Form Prohibition
do
read
eat
drink

Linking Sentences

We already learned the words and that mean "and" when combining nouns. Instead of those words, we use the -form to link verbs together in Japanese sentences.

  • means " I will close the door and open the window."

  • means "I ate the apple and drank the water."

For the examples above, notice how the -form is used for the first verb regardless of the tense of the overall sentence. Only the final verb indicates the tense in this construction.

skills.name: Classroom 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
He said, she said!

When you are quoting what someone said or telling someone what something is called, you would use the particle . You can think of kind of like quotation marks in English, with the phrase coming before being the phrase that would be in quotes. Since there's no opening quotation mark like there would be with a quote in English, though, you sometimes have to figure out from context which words are being quoted.

Japanese English
He said "No."

Be careful, because using the wrong particle can sometimes greatly change the meaning of your sentence.

Japanese English
Please call me "John."
Please call John.

Counting Long Things

() is another Japanese counter word, and it is used to count long, cylindrical things like pens and pencils. Be careful, because the pronunciation of also changes depending on the number before it!

Kanji Reading Meaning
(ippon) one (long, cylindrical thing)
(nihon) two (long, cylindrical things)
(sanbon) three (long, cylindrical things)
(yonhon) four (long, cylindrical things)
(gohon) five (long, cylindrical things)
(roppon) six (long, cylindrical things)
(nanahon) seven (long, cylindrical things)
(happon) eight (long, cylindrical things)
(kyuuhon) nine (long, cylindrical things)
(juppon) ten (long, cylindrical things)

skills.name: Feelings 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Past-Tense -Adjectives

To turn an -adjective from the present to the past tense, you remove the -ending and replace with . Adding a at the end will turn it into the polite form. See the example below.

Sentence Translation
This is delicious.
This was delicious.

Just like with the other forms of the -adjectives, you're allowed to drop the ending in casual conversation.

Sentence Translation
This was delicious.

skills.name: Direction 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Big and Small

There a few adjectives that have both an - and a - adjective form. With these adjectives, it is common to use the - adjective form when the adjective comes before the noun it is modifying. "Big" and "small" are two such adjectives.

- adjective - adjective Meaning
() () big, large
() () small
Japanese English
That bank is big.
That is a big bank.

Big or Wide?

The word () means "wide" and () means "narrow," but these words are often used in Japanese in situations in which we'd use the words "big" or "small" in English. For instance, when you're describing the internal area of a room as "large," you usually use the word rather than . is sometimes also translated as "spacious."

Japanese English
This hospital is spacious. (large inside)
This room is small. (narrow inside)

Where?

Japanese has different levels of formality, and sometimes there are different words with the same meaning that differ by formality level. You'll encounter some of them in this skill.

Casual Formal Meaning
here, this way (close to the speaker)
there, that way (close to the listener)
over there, over that way (far from both the listener and the speaker)
where?, which direction?

skills.name: Object
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Thin and Thick

Just like counter words, different adjectives are sometimes used depending on the objects being described. When you are talking about something being "thin," you would use a different adjective depending on the shape of the object being described.

Japanese English
() thin (for long, cylindrical things)
() thin (for flat things)

There are also multiple words meaning "thick," and their usage differs based on the shape of the object being described, too.

Japanese English
() thick (for long, cylindrical things)
() thick (for flat things)

Is it thick or is it hot?

Remember, kanji matters! Although the three words below have the same reading, the meaning completely changes if you select the wrong kanji!

Japanese English
() thick (for flat things)
() hot (weather)
() hot (object)

skills.name: Shopping 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
This lesson introduces the very fundamentals of also known as "respect language," as applied to verbs. Believe it or not, you've already learned some respect language, such as in the phrases "" or "" Just like those phrases, the extra-polite constructions we introduce in this chapter also begin with

We learned from earlier lessons that the most common way of asking someone to do something is with the -form, often followed by

Japanese English
Please wait. (ordinary form)

To make the request extremely humble and polite, we take the stem of the verb from its form and add an prefix. It's as simple as that. Although you are unlikely to use this form on a brief trip to Japan, you are certain to hear it from shopkeepers and restaurant employees.

Japanese English
Please wait. (ultra-polite form)

skills.name: Clothes 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Counting Words for Clothing

Below is a table for and the counting words introduced in this lesson. is a counter that counts pairs of things you put on your feet, while counts other kinds of pairs, such as pairs of gloves. is a counter for suits, jackets, and kimono.

Number Form of Form of Form of

skills.name: Hobby 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The Plain Form

We use the "plain," "short" or "dictionary" form first and foremost to express the present or future tense in a casual conversation, such as between friends. We also use it to express these tenses in certain other situations before the end of a sentence.

Without exception, all plain form verbs end in a [u] sound. In the examples below, see how the plain form endings correlate with the construction of the -form.

English Kanji Plain Form -Form
eat
give -
read
fly
buy
use

Nominalizing Verbs with the Plain Form +

You can use the construction to talk about things you like doing. In the example below, (swim) is the plain form of verb When you add to the plain form, the translation becomes either to swim or swimming. The sentence ends with which means "I like."

  • Therefore, means "I like swimming" or "I like to swim."

Remember that you can add additional information to any sentence to provide more context.

  • For example, means "I like swimming in the ocean."

Below is a table of sample sentences that model this construction.

Object Verb Adverb
  • means "My running is fast" or "I run fast."
  • means "Your swimming is skilled" or "you are good at swimming."
  • means "My tennis playing is poor" or "I am bad at playing tennis."
  • means "I like watching anime" or "I like to watch anime."

skills.name: Classroom 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
form: Negative Request

is a negative request with the -form ( becomes ). The first two types are called Godan (u-verbs), which you change the /u/ sound ending into /a/ sound + nai to make the negative form.

u-verbs: (-u) (-anai)

ru-verbs: (ru) (nai)

Type Verb Plain Negative Negative Request
Godan line up
Godan go
Ichidan look
Ichidan quit
Irregular come
Irregular do

skills.name: Health 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The Plain Past Form

We use the "plain past" form or "short past" form first and foremost to express the past tense in a casual conversation, such as between friends. We also use it to express the past tense in certain other situations.

This form is constructed by taking the -form of a verb and replacing with (if it ends in ) or (if it ends in ).

English Kanji Plain Form -Form Plain Past
eat
buy
read

Just like when we create the -form, verbs that end in or in the plain form have irregular endings.

English Kanji Plain Form -Form Plain Past
write
swim

skills.name: Post Office
skills.tipsAndNotes:
I would like...

NOUN+ and VERB STEM+ are two ways to express that you want something. However, Japanese speakers often desire to be less direct, which is considered more polite. You can do that by adding or to the end of a request to make it less blunt. In English, you can translate sentences containing this ending as "I would like..."

Japanese English
I want to send a postcard.
I would like to send a postcard.
I want you to call a taxi.
I would like you to call a taxi.

skills.name: The City
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Maid Cafes?

There are many things you can find in Japan that aren't common in other countries. Want to dress up as your favorite anime character and get your photo taken on the street? Visit a cafe where the waitresses all dress like maids? You can find all that and more in Japan!

Japanese English Notes
Maid Cafe In maid cafes, the servers dress up like maids!
Otaku The word "otaku" is usually used in English to refer to someone who is obsessed with anime and manga, but the word is used for many other things in Japan. For instance, did you know that a is someone who is obsessed with trains?
Cosplay "Cosplay" refers to dressing up as characters, usually from anime, manga, or video games. It is short for "costume play."

Ride the Yamanote Line!

There are a lot of interesting and trendy areas in Tokyo, so it can be helpful to know their names if you ever choose to visit.

Japanese Reading

Harajuku and Shibuya are both known for their fashion - Harajuku for street fashion and Shibuya for having many large department stores for shopping! Harajuku is a great place to go if you like to cosplay. Akihabara and Ikebukuro are interesting places for an otaku - you can buy video games, anime and manga, computer parts, and all kinds of other things! And Shinjuku is well-known for its exciting nightlife.

The () or "Yamanote Line" is a train line in Tokyo that goes in a circle, and it makes stops in all the areas listed above. It might be better to avoid riding the train at rush hour, though - otherwise you might run into lots of (office workers) going to and from work, and the train might be too packed for you to get on!

skills.name: Olympic Games
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The Olympics!

Are you looking forward to the Olympics? If you are, you can tell people that you are looking forward to something by using the phrase - or if you want to be more polite. What Olympic sport are you looking forward to the most? Who do you hope will win the (gold medal)?

Japanese English
! I am looking forward to the Olympics!

skills.name: Ability
skills.tipsAndNotes:
There are several ways of expressing one's ability to do something in Japanese.

Potential Form

The first and more casual way is the potential form of the verb, which changes the usual verb ending into a form that rhymes with or Notice how the potential form ending changes in accordance with the original ending.

Regular Forms Potential "Can-Do" Forms

When using this form, you may notice that the particle plays a major role in describing what would normally be the object of a sentence marked with This is because the potential form often translates better to "is able to be" than "can."

Regular Examples Potential "Can-Do" Examples
look at a book see a book
listen to music hear music

Using

The second and more formal to express ability is with the verb sometimes spelled Ordinarily, the short form of a verb attaches to the word to signify someone's ability to do something.

Regular Examples Examples
dance can dance
escape can escape

Verbs

For verbs that end in or one has no choice but to express ability with The more casual way to do this is with by itself.

Regular Examples Examples
study can study
exercise can exercise

To make the form more formal, you can add to the end of the verb instead.

Regular Examples Examples
study can study
exercise can exercise

skills.name: Favors
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Expressing favors in Japanese makes frequent use of the -form in coordination with a set of special verbs for giving and receiving.

We use when we ourselves do a favor for someone else. We also use it when the interaction involves only other people.

Example Translation
I bought flowers for you.
Honda bought flowers for Tanaka.

We use when we ourselves do a favor for someone of a lower social status, such as a child or a pet. This also applies when the interaction involves only other people.

Example Translation
I bought flowers for my daughter.
Honda bought flowers for his daughter.

We use when someone else does a favor for us.

Example Translation
He bought flowers for me.

We use when the topic of the sentence is the one to receive the favor, as "" literally means "receive." This is often translated as "had (someone) do (something)."

Example Translation
I had my mother buy (me) flowers.
She had her boyfriend buy (her) flowers.

You may recognize the verb from the phrase which is said before eating. is a polite form of usually used when asking for a favor. In addition to one can use the verb for a more casual tone.

Example Translation
Would you please buy me flowers?
Would you mind buying me flowers?

skills.name: Nature 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Onomatopoeia

The Japanese language features many words that are known as onomatopoeia - a word that is named by a vocal imitation of the sound associated with it. One of these words is , which means "sparkling." It is meant to mimic the sound one might imagine a glittering diamond or star might make. can be used as a - verb () or paired with the verb () to further emphasize the sparkle.

In Japanese, onomatopoeia can be commonly written in either hiragana () or (), depending on what you prefer stylistically.

skills.name: Ecology
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Counting Large Animals

Remember, the counter word () is used to count small animals. Have you wondered how you would count large animals? You would use the counter word () instead! Thankfully, the kanji is read the same way () regardless of the number of large animals you are counting!

Kanji Reading Meaning
(ittou) one (large animal)
(nitou) two (large animals)
(santou) three (large animals)
(yontou) four (large animals)
(gotou) five (large animals)
(rokutou) six (large animals)
(nanatou) seven (large animals)
(hattou) eight (large animals)
(kyuutou) nine (large animals)
(juttou) or (jittou) ten (large animals)

Hardly Any

is a word that can be used in a negative sentence to mean hardly any or hardly (at all) or almost no Below are a few examples of its usage.

Japanese English
I could hardly believe it.
There is almost no oil in Japan.

skills.name: Condition
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Appearance

When expressing appearance in Japanese, one can choose from several grammatical expressions.

Using the noun is the most basic way of expressing something's outward appearance.

Example Translation
He looks busy.

The noun is used almost exactly like only it has a more casual tone. Be careful not to treat it as a verb or an adjective, although it might look like one.

Example Translation
It looks old.

The noun is used to express how something seems or appears to be based on one's observation. It's more of an educated guess and less of a certainty than or

is also used to describe hearsay gathered from other people. In this instance, the grammar of the word changes slightly. Verbs, for example, change from the stem form for appearance to the short form for hearsay.

Example Translation
It seems like it will rain.
I hear that it will rain.

With respect to hearsay, is used in similar contexts as only it acts like any other -adjective would.

Example Translation
I hear that movie is fun.

Degree

This lesson also introduces the concept of nouns formed from adjectives, much like how "sweet" becomes "sweetness" in English with an additional ending. The ability or inability to measure such nouns in Japanese plays an important role in how they are formed.

If a quality can be measured objectively, its nominal form will end in This is also the case for all -adjectives, regardless of one's ability to measure them.

Adjective Noun
big size
long length
tall height
heavy weight
convenient convenience
pretty prettiness

If, however, a quality cannot be measured objectively, its nominal form will almost always end in especially if it is a feeling or flavor.

Adjective Noun
painful pain
sad sadness
sweet sweetness
tasty tastiness

skills.name: Possibilities
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Japanese, there are four different expressions that translate to the English word "if."

- Natural Consequence

We use the word when something is a natural, inevitable, and predictable consequence of something else. This cannot be a personal intention. It is often used when describing facts and operations, instructions, and habitual actions.

Example Translation
If tires are old, they are dangerous.

- Future Speculation

We use when expressing that something will take effect in a certain context. This is often a personal intention about the future based on a given assumption about what will happen.

Example Translation
If everyone is going, I will go as well.

- Conditional Focus

We can use the form of a verb to express a conditional sentence in almost any context. However, it is ungrammatical to use this construction when the subject is the same in both parts of the sentence and the sentence expresses a desire or prohibition. It places a special focus on what comes before it, and the outcome is usually good. The form sounds rather formal, so it's often used for writing and polite speech.

Example Translation
If you take this medicine, you will get better.

- Consequence Focus

The use of or to end a past-tense verb presents the fewest restrictions and greatest freedom for expressing a conditional sentence in Japanese. It is often used for hypotheticals and speculations that have yet to be proven, much like the construction "if ... would ..." in English. It places a special focus on what comes after it. This is the only construction that is grammatical for a past event, or when the subject is the same in both parts of the sentence and the sentence expresses a desire or prohibition. Please refer to the example sentences below.

Example Translation
I got sick when I ate too much.
Example Translation
You must not ride your bike if you drink alcohol.

When in doubt about which form of "if" to use, or is usually a safe bet.

- Conditional Warning

The word cannot express "if" by itself. Rather, it is a supplemental word generally used at the beginning of a sentence to express that a conditional is coming. It generates a backdrop of uncertainty about the information ahead.

Example Translation
Supposing you do not have time, tomorrow would also be alright.

skills.name: Science 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
How to measure?

In Japanese, similar words often use different kanji characters in order to express different nuance. For instance, the character for to measure differs depending on the thing youre measuring! All the words below are read and all of them mean to measure, but the situations in which you would use each are different.

Japanese English
to measure (weight or volume)
to measure (quantities, time, temperature)
to measure (length, depth, width, speed)

If a quality can be measured objectively, its nominal form will end in This is also the case for all -adjectives, regardless of one's ability to measure them.

Adjective Noun
big size
long length
tall height
heavy weight
convenient convenience
pretty prettiness

skills.name: Emergency 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Transitive and Intransitive Verb Pairs

Remember, transitive verbs are verbs that take a direct object, while intransitive verbs are verbs that do not take a direct object. Transitive and intransitive verbs often occur in pairs, and their meaning and usage differs.

Japanese English
() take place, occur (intransitive)
() cause (transitive)

Remember that the particle is used to mark the direct object of a sentence, so you would always use it with a transitive verb.

Japanese English
An accident occurred.
I caused an accident.

skills.name: Transportation 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
As.as possible

is a phrase meaning as much as possible or as much as one can. Depending on the subject of the sentence, the exact translation of the phrase can change, however.

Japanese English
Please come here as soon as you can.
He ran as fast as he could.
I need as much time as possible.

skills.name: Education
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Only

There are two ways to express the idea of only or just in Japanese. One of them is with the word , which is used with affirmative sentences.

Japanese English
I will give you only a hundred yen.
I am just looking.

Another way you can express this idea is with the word , which has the same meaning but is used with negative sentences in Japanese, although the meaning of the sentence is not translated in the negative.

Japanese English
Only Mrs. Tanaka is in this room.
I have only one Japanese dictionary.

Several

() is a prefix that can be added to some words to mean several. or a few Some examples are below.

Kanji Reading Meaning
a few people, several people
a few years, several years
a few times, several times

skills.name: Work 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Transitive and Intransitive Verb Pairs

The English language has certain sets of verbs that are related to each other but behave differently in a sentence. Transitive verbs like "raise" or "lay" always take a grammatical object. However, intransitive verbs like "rise" or "lie" never do. The same principle works in Japanese, with the examples below.

Transitive Verbs (take an object)

Japanese English
raise (something)
lower (something)

Intransitive Verbs (no object)

Japanese English
rise
fall

So how do you know if and when a verb is transitive or intransitive in Japanese? Aside from noticing which verbs do and do not take grammatical objects, there are a few spelling patterns that can act as clues.

  • Transitive verbs often end in -sounds or like the verbs () ()or ()
  • Their intransitive pairings often end in -sounds, like the verbs () or ()

Greetings at Work

Greetings and set phrases are an extremely important part of Japanese work culture. Below is a sampling of some of the most important points.

Phrase Occasion
A standard morning greeting, occasionally shorted to or simply a loud hiss.
A mid-day greeting to acknowledge that someone is doing such a good job that they look tired from doing so.
A routine apology said when entering or leaving a room.
A routine apology said when leaving work before other people do so.
A routine response to "", acknowledging that the coworker's hard work has been appreciated.

skills.name: Numbers
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Only

There are two ways to express the idea of only or just in Japanese. One of them is with the word , which is used with affirmative sentences.

Japanese English
I will give you only a hundred yen.
I am just looking.

Another way you can express this idea is with the word , which has the same meaning but is used with negative sentences in Japanese, although the meaning of the sentence is not translated in the negative.

Japanese English
Only Mrs. Tanaka is in this room.
I have only one Japanese dictionary.

Several

() is a prefix that can be added to some words to mean several. or a few Some examples are below.

Kanji Reading Meaning
a few people, several people
a few years, several years
a few times, several times

In order to

The phrase has many different uses in Japanese. One of the meanings is in order to (perform an action). In this construction AB would be I did B in order to A, in which follows a verb in the short form. Some examples are listed below.

Japanese English
My father put on his glasses in order to read the newspaper.
I transferred planes twice to come to this island.

skills.name: Obligations
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Obligations

Two grammatical elements in Japanese are especially important when describing responsibility and expectation.

The noun describes the way something is expected to be.

Example Translation
Doctors are supposed to study medicine.

The noun however, describes responsibilities and obligations with a more moralistic bent.

Example Translation
I should go to school.

Because can come across as harsh, it is most often used to describe one's own obligations. For talking about other people, "" is often used instead.

Example Translation
You should go to school.

Causative Form

The causative form is used to express the fact when someone lets or forces someone to do something. It is created by adding a form of or to the end of a verb stem. When the person who is requested to perform the action is followed by this usually translates to "let someone do something."

Example Translation
They let him go to the US.

When this person is followed by however, this usually implies that the person had no choice in the matter.

Example Translation
They made him go to the US.

This distinction is not a hard-and-fast rule, however, and the context of the sentence is usually enough to determine the difference. Either English translation is possible for either of the Japanese sentences above.

skills.name: Desires 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Sentence-Ending Particles and

Oftentimes when you want to express your positive emotions in Japanese, you end the sentence with either or with the latter expressing an even deeper sense of longing for something. This particle does not translate directly into English, but it often acts similarly to the previously-introduced particle which establishes a "harmony of understanding" between the speaker and listener.

Example Translation Emotional Depth
Isn't that nice! neutral
Isn't that nice! medium
Isn't that nice! high

Volitional Form

This course introduced the polite phrase relatively early on. This usually translates to "let's ... " but not always. If the speaker is referring to an action that is intended to be done alone, it translates better as "I will," a kind of definitive affirmation of one's desire to do something.

Example Translation
I will go to the bank.

This lesson introduces the casual form of , which is some iteration of or depending on the ending of the verb in question.

Example Translation
I will go to the bank.
Let's eat pizza.
Let's play outside.

skills.name: Thoughts
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Talking and Thinking About Something

N+ is a phrase used in Japanese to discuss a topic being talked or thought about. It can be translated as regarding.... or about...

Japanese English
I talked about this problem.
I need to think about this.

As Expected

() is a phrase used in Japanese to express that something is as expected. It can be used following a verb (usually in the short form past tense) or a noun. Directly following a noun, the pronunciation sometimes changes to , such as in the phrase (), which means as promised.

Japanese English
Do as I taught you.
I did my homework as promised.

skills.name: Society
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Cities and Prefectures

Japan is divided into different areas, which are known as prefectures. Most of these areas will be identified by adding the character () to the end of the areas name. For instance, if you lived in Yamaguchi prefecture, you would tell people you live in ().

If youre talking about a city, you would usually add the character () to the end of the place name. So if you lived in Chiba City, you would tell people you live in ().

Did you know that sometimes a prefecture will contain a city of the same name? So if you live in Chiba City, Chiba Prefecture, you would live in both () and ()!

As a.

When discussing someones role, you can use the word in Japanese. The word comes after the noun or role that is being discussed. In English, its often translated to the word as.

Japanese English
I said my opinion as a friend.
Mr. Yamaguchi is working as a teacher at a local high school.

skills.name: Memories
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Passive Voice

The passive voice in Japanese is a verb form that is unique to each verb ending, yet it is always some iteration of or

Active Voice Passive Voice

Remember that the topic or subject of a passive sentence is the recipient of the given action, and as such, it takes the or particle instead of

Example Translation
The apple was eaten.

When the passive sentence includes a causative agent, this person or thing is marked with

Example Translation
The apple was eaten by me.

skills.name: Law
skills.tipsAndNotes:
It just happened!

When you are describing an event that just occurred, you can use the phrase . The phrase follows directly after a verb in the short form. If the verb is in the non-past tense, it describes an action that is just about to happen. If the verb is in the past tense, it describes an event that just happened.

Japanese English
The train just left.
I was about to go to the movies.

skills.name: Honorifics
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Formal Language

This lesson showcases some of the most common instances of formal language for use in business situations.

Nouns

To make a noun extra formal, one places an prefix before a word of Japanese origin (typically a word with a single kanji) and a prefix before a word of Chinese origin (typically a word with two kanji). We already learned a few examples earlier in the course.

Ordinary Formal
()
()
()
()
()

Sometimes a noun will change completely in the transition from ordinary to formal language, often reflecting a parallel change in another part of speech, such as a verb.

Ordinary Formal
() ()
() ()

Adjectives

Adjectives typically do not change grammatical form in formal speech, but they are replaced with more formal varieties.

Ordinary Formal
() ()

Verbs

For verbs, there is a mixed system. As introduced in an earlier lesson, some verbs adopt an prefix and may adopt the use of the copula

Ordinary Formal

Meanwhile, some verbs are replaced with more formal variants.

Ordinary Formal
() (one's own actions)
(someone else's actions)
()
(written form)
(spoken form)
()

Remember that formal language uses the polite form at the end of each sentence. Ending a formal sentence with the plain form, or sounds odd and incongruous with the context.

skills.name: The Hotel
skills.tipsAndNotes:
An Overnight Stay

When youre staying overnight somewhere, you would use the counter word () to count the number of nights you stay somewhere. Please take note that some of the readings are irregular!

Kanji Reading Meaning
(ippaku) one (night of a stay)
(nihaku) two (nights of a stay)
(sanpaku) three (nights of a stay)
(yonhaku) four (nights of a stay)
(gohaku) five (nights of a stay)
(roppaku) six (nights of a stay)
(nanahaku) seven (nights of a stay)
(happaku) eight (nights of a stay)
(kyuuhaku) nine (nights of a stay)
(juppaku) ten (nights of a stay)

Below are some example sentences.

Japanese English
I spent three nights in Nagoya.
This hotel is forty thousand yen for one night.

In a certain place

You can use the word before a noun to specify that youre talking about a certain thing without going into specifics about it.

Japanese English
He stayed at a certain hotel.
I always keep my valuables in a certain place.

skills.name: Nature 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Counting Large Animals

Remember, the counter word () is used to count small animals. Have you wondered how you would count large animals? You would use the counter word () instead! Thankfully, the kanji is read the same way () regardless of the number of large animals you are counting!

Kanji Reading Meaning
(ittou) one (large animal)
(nitou) two (large animals)
(santou) three (large animals)
(yontou) four (large animals)
(gotou) five (large animals)
(rokutou) six (large animals)
(nanatou) seven (large animals)
(hattou) eight (large animals)
(kyuutou) nine (large animals)
(juttou) or (jittou) ten (large animals)

Hardly Any

is a word that can be used in a negative sentence to mean hardly any or hardly (at all) or almost no Below are a few examples of its usage.

Japanese English
I could hardly believe it.
There is almost no oil in Japan.

skills.name: Casual 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Casual Language

Welcome to the casual language in the Japanese course! The reason that colloquial language is listed late in the tree is that we wanted you to understand the importance of politeness when speaking with strangers or coworkers.

When you speak with friends in casual settings or watch anime, you may hear a lot of expressions that you have yet to be introduced to.

Pronouns

There are two male pronouns reserved for casual settings, (), meaning "I" or "me," and () meaning "you." In formal settings, use of these pronouns is considered confrontational and impolite. Both and sound extremely rough and masculine, which is why typically they are reserved for boys or men who are teenagers or older.

In addition, you may hear women and girls use the pronoun (sometimes written ) to refer to themselves. This is not considered as polite as but considerably more so than

Particle Dropping

In polite and written Japanese, grammatical particles that mark parts of speech, such as and see heavy use. However, in more casual settings, they are often dropped when the meaning is clear without them. In Japanese just as in English, formality and sentence length go hand-in-hand.

Formal Casual

skills.name: Tech 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
I didnt mean to!

When youve done something unintentionally, you can use the word to emphasize the fact that it was an accident. Its often paired with the V+ form, and its generally used to express regret over having done something you know you shouldnt have done.

Japanese English
Even when I am talking with my friends, I wind up looking at my smartphone unintentionally.

This sentence has a connotation of something like, I wind up looking at my smartphone (even though I know that I shouldnt).

You can also use the word to express that youve done something carelessly or accidentally.

Japanese English
I carelessly forgot to turn off the air conditioner.

skills.name: People 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
and

In this skill, youll encounter words about men and women and boys and girls, and youll see some different expressions you might use to talk about them. The word for woman is () and the word for man is (), but it is more polite to use the expressions () and () instead. There are also the expressions () and () which mean girl and boy respectively. Did you notice that the polite expressions for man and woman use the character for "person" - () while the expressions for boy and girl use the character for child - ()?

Japanese Reading English
woman
man
woman (more polite)
man (more polite)
girl
boy

Death

Much like English, Japanese has more than one way to talk about death. The different words have different connotations, similar to the English language expressions died and passed away.

Japanese Reading English
died
passed away

skills.name: Four Seasons
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Did you know that Japan has four seasons?

Many who have visited Japan have been asked this question, and for good reason. Unlike in many parts of the world, the four seasons in Japan are quite distinct and a core part of Japanese culture. The cyclical nature of the year has been celebrated on the archipelago for millennia with festivals, rituals, and seasonal food.

Spring is the traditional start of the year, a time of new beginnings, a new school year, and a new year on the business calendar. Cherry blossoms bloom throughout Japan to mark the transition into spring. Families and friends gather underneath the blossoming trees and have picnics with rice dumplings () and various beverages.

Summer is remarkably hot and humid throughout Japan, especially in areas away from the mountains or the sea. Summer festivals offer a respite from the heat with flavored shaved ice () and cool drinks. Near the end of summer, many in Japan return to their hometowns to celebrate the Bon Festival, a holiday to commemorate the spirits of one's ancestors.

Autumn is the season when the maple leaves turn a colorful spectrum of red, orange, and gold. The weather cools down, and the true bounty of the harvest takes the form of the many delicacies available at this time, including baked sweet potato and a warming, broth-based stew ().

Winter is the season for heavy snow in the mountains of central Japan and throughout the north and northwest of the country. On New Years, Japanese people traditionally eat long buckwheat noodles () as a wish for future health and longevity. Department stores celebrate the new year with mystery grab bags. Sapporo holds its annual snow festival in February, complete with enormous sculptures that attract visitors from around the world.
